questions.prompt: Why did Holmes prefer unusual cases?

choices.text: He worked for the love of his art, not wealth
He was ordered to by the police

questions.explanation: Watson notes that Holmes worked for the love of his art rather than for the acquirement of wealth.

questions.prompt: How many cases did Watson study over eight years?
questions.explanation: Watson refers to 'the seventy odd cases' he studied over the last eight years.

questions.prompt: What does 'none commonplace' suggest about Holmes's work?
questions.explanation: By saying none were commonplace, Watson emphasizes that every case Holmes took was unusual or remarkable.

questions.prompt: What was unusual about Holmes being awake early?

choices.text: He was normally a late riser
He was always up before Watson

questions.explanation: Watson notes that Holmes 'was a late riser, as a rule,' making his early morning appearance surprising.

questions.prompt: What time was it when Watson woke?
questions.explanation: The clock on the mantelpiece showed it was a quarter-past seven.

questions.prompt: Why did Watson feel resentment at being woken?

choices.text: He valued his regular habits and routine
He had been out late the night before

questions.explanation: Watson was 'regular in my habits,' so being disturbed early disrupted his routine.

questions.prompt: Who arrived at their door early in the morning?

choices.text: A young lady in a state of excitement

questions.explanation: Holmes tells Watson that 'a young lady has arrived in a considerable state of excitement.'

questions.prompt: What does 'knocked up' mean in this context?
questions.explanation: In Victorian British English, 'knocked up' means to be woken by someone knocking at the door.

questions.prompt: What chain of events does Holmes describe?

choices.text: The client woke Mrs. Hudson, who woke Holmes, who woke Watson
Watson woke Holmes who woke Mrs. Hudson
Mrs. Hudson woke everyone at once

questions.explanation: Holmes explains the chain: Mrs. Hudson was knocked up (by the client), she retorted upon Holmes, and Holmes upon Watson.

questions.prompt: Why does Holmes assume the matter is pressing?

choices.text: The young lady told him so
Young ladies don't normally visit at this early hour

questions.explanation: Holmes reasons that when young ladies 'wander about the metropolis at this hour,' it must be something very pressing.

questions.prompt: Why did Holmes wake Watson?

choices.text: He wanted to give Watson the chance to follow the case
Watson asked to be woken early

questions.explanation: Holmes says he thought Watson would 'wish to follow it from the outset.'

questions.prompt: What does 'metropolis' refer to?

choices.text: A large, busy city like London

questions.explanation: Metropolis refers to a very large city, in this case London where Holmes and Watson lived.

questions.prompt: What did Watson enjoy most?

choices.text: Following Holmes in his professional investigations

questions.explanation: Watson states he 'had no keener pleasure than in following Holmes in his professional investigations.'

questions.prompt: What does Watson admire about Holmes's deductions?

choices.text: They were swift like intuitions yet logically founded
They were always wrong at first

questions.explanation: Watson admires deductions 'as swift as intuitions, and yet always founded on a logical basis.'

questions.prompt: How quickly did Watson get ready?
questions.explanation: Watson 'rapidly threw on my clothes and was ready in a few minutes.'

questions.prompt: How was the lady dressed?

choices.text: In black with a heavy veil

questions.explanation: The text describes 'a lady dressed in black and heavily veiled.'

questions.prompt: Why does Holmes introduce Watson as someone she can speak freely before?

choices.text: To put her at ease and assure her of Watson's discretion
Because Watson already knows the case

questions.explanation: Holmes assures the lady she can trust Watson, putting her at ease to share her story freely.

questions.prompt: What does 'intimate friend' mean here?

choices.text: A very close and trusted friend

questions.explanation: In this context, 'intimate friend' means a very close, trusted companion and associate.

questions.prompt: How did Holmes know the lady came by train?

choices.text: He observed a return ticket in her glove

questions.explanation: Holmes observed 'the second half of a return ticket in the palm of your left glove.'

questions.prompt: What does this observation reveal about Holmes?

choices.text: He has extraordinary attention to small details
He already knew who she was
He was guessing to impress her

questions.explanation: Holmes's ability to notice a ticket stub in someone's glove demonstrates his extraordinary powers of observation.

questions.prompt: What was Holmes's tone when speaking to the woman?
questions.explanation: Holmes spoke 'soothingly, bending forward and patting her forearm,' showing care and reassurance.

questions.prompt: What is the visitor's name?
questions.explanation: She introduces herself as 'Helen Stoner.'

questions.prompt: Who is Helen's stepfather?

choices.text: The last survivor of the Roylott family of Stoke Moran

questions.explanation: Helen describes her stepfather as 'the last survivor of one of the oldest Saxon families in England, the Roylotts of Stoke Moran.'

questions.prompt: What might 'the name is familiar to me' suggest about Holmes?

choices.text: He has encountered the Roylott family before or heard of them

questions.explanation: Holmes recognizing the family name suggests he has broad knowledge or has previously come across the Roylotts.

questions.prompt: What is causing the woman to shiver?
questions.explanation: She explicitly states: 'It is fear, Mr. Holmes. It is terror.'

questions.prompt: How is Helen described when she raises her veil?

choices.text: Face drawn and grey with frightened eyes

questions.explanation: Her face was 'all drawn and grey, with restless frightened eyes.'

questions.prompt: What does her physical state suggest about her situation?

choices.text: She has been under prolonged stress and danger
She is simply tired from travel

questions.explanation: Her 'pitiable state of agitation' and drawn appearance suggest sustained fear and ongoing danger rather than a momentary shock.

questions.prompt: What does Holmes offer the woman?
questions.explanation: Holmes says 'I shall order you a cup of hot coffee.'

questions.prompt: What kind of menace does the narrator describe?
questions.explanation: The text describes 'a menace that is constant and inescapable,' suggesting an ongoing and unavoidable danger.

questions.prompt: What does 'deep-seated anxiety' mean?

choices.text: A worry that is deeply rooted and long-standing

questions.explanation: Deep-seated means firmly established, suggesting the anxiety is profound and has been building over time.
